case_vignette: A 14-year-old boy is brought to the physician for the evaluation of back pain for the past six months. The pain is worse with exercise and when reclining. He attends high school and is on the swim team. He also states that he lifts weights on a regular basis. He has not had any trauma to the back or any previous problems with his joints. He has no history of serious illness. His father has a disc herniation. Palpation of the spinous processes at the lumbosacral area shows that two adjacent vertebrae are displaced and are at different levels. Muscle strength is normal. Sensation to pinprick and light touch is intact throughout. When the patient is asked to walk, a waddling gait is noted. Passive raising of either the right or left leg causes pain radiating down the ipsilateral leg.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having back pain for the past six months that gets worse when I exercise or lie down.
How old are you?
I am 14 years old.
Are you male or female?
I am a male.
Have you had any recent injuries to your back?
No, I haven't had any injuries to my back.
Do you experience any pain in other areas of your body?
Yes, when I lift my legs, I feel pain shooting down the same side of my leg.
Have you noticed any weakness, numbness, or tingling in your legs or feet?
My muscle strength feels normal and I can feel things just fine when touched or pricked with something sharp all over.
Have you experienced any unintended weight loss or night sweats?
No, I haven't experienced any unintended weight loss or night sweats.
Does the pain improve with any particular activity or position?
No, it seems to get worse with exercise and when I recline.
Do any of your family members have a history of joint or spine conditions?
Yes, my father has a disc herniation.
Do you have any bladder control problems or a change in bowel habits?
No, I haven't had any issues like that.
Final Diagnosis: Probable lumbar disc herniation.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A 14-year-old male presents with back pain that worsens with exercise and lying down. He reports feeling shooting pain down the same side of his leg when lifting his legs. Muscle strength and sensation are normal. The patient denies any unintended weight loss or night sweats. His father has a history of disc herniation, but the patient has not experienced any similar issues.
trial_0.singleturn_frq: **Final Diagnosis:** Mechanical back pain, possible discogenic pain or spinal pathology. Further investigation needed.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I've been having back pain for six months now that gets worse when I exercise, lay back, or lift weights.
How old are you?
I'm 14 years old.
Are you currently taking any medications?
No, I'm not taking any medications.
Have you had any injuries to your back or any other parts of your body recently?
No, I haven't had any trauma to my back.
Does the pain improve with rest or changing positions?
Yes, the pain is worse when I recline or exercise.
Do you have any morning stiffness in your back or other joints that improves with activity?
I haven't mentioned anything about morning stiffness or how it changes with activity.
Do you have any other symptoms such as fever, unexplained weight loss, or changes in bowel or bladder control?
No, I haven't mentioned having a fever, weight loss, or changes in my bowel or bladder control.
Do you have any family history of back problems or autoimmune diseases?
My father has a disc herniation.
Is the pain localized to one area or does it radiate to other parts of your body, such as your legs?

The patient has not mentioned morning stiffness or how the pain changes with activity, nor experiencing fever, weight loss, or changes in bowel or bladder control. The patient's father has a disc herniation and the pain radiates down the leg when either leg is lifted passively.
